Joe -

In general, I like it.

It seems to start off well, but I might rephrase it near the end, in order to stay away from sounding like it is a "bad day".

To someone's point, possibly provide the link to google - in case they truly don't know what it means to "Google it" [OT - when will that make it to the dictionary].  Additionally (to the "bad day" effect), you might want to rephrase the RTFF, into something a little more tame, but still to the point that we all have bad days.

Finally, I would question the use of "SPECIFIC question" at the end,...maybe just stick with  "If you still haven't found what you are looking for, please feel free to send your question/query to junit@yahoogroups.com."  Very often, we have lively/interesting/entertaining discussions that aren't really formed around a "SPECIFIC question".  We might end up restricting things too much.


my two cents,
Dianne

-------------- Original message -------------- 
What do you think?
------
Welcome to the JUnit Yahoo! group.

We know you want to ask your question NOW, but if you read on, you can
probably get your answer FASTER.

Please check out these resources:

JUnit FAQ                    http://tinyurl.com/a98ah
Tutorials                    http://tinyurl.com/a5h4z
Asking a question            http://tinyurl.com/anel
To unsubscribe               e-mail junit-unsubscribe@yahoogroups.com

We continue to have SPAM problems, so your first few e-mails will be
moderated. Obvious SPAM, overly-general questions and other off-topic
posts will be REJECTED, so please consult the above resources before you
ask your question.

If Google can answer your question, then you can get unstuck
IMMEDIATELY. You can also avoid responses like "READ THE F$@#&*ING FAQ!"
(We try to be polite, but everyone has bad days.)


When you're ready to send your SPECIFIC question about how to use JUnit,
how JUnit is designed or where JUnit is going, send e-mail to
junit@yahoogroups.com

Thanks, and welcome!
-- 
J. B. (Joe) Rainsberger
Diaspar Software Services
http://www.diasparsoftware.com
2005 Gordon Pask Award Winner for contribution to Agile practice
Author, JUnit Recipes: Practical Methods for Programmer Testing
